name: flax straw production, dew-retted | flax straw, dew-retted | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/30600/documentation

The data refer to fibre flax cultivation and retting in Western Europe (France, Belgium and the Netherlands), the 1st step to produce European Flax™ fibre. European Flax™ is a certification of origin and traceability owned by the Alliance for European Flax-Linen and Hemp (formerly known as CELC) which covers 100% of the fibres obtained from western European retted flax plants, and guarantees third party verified traceability downstream. The unit is 1kg of flax straw, dew-retted in 2014-2028 through Flax cultivation, retting and harvesting. Cultivation is modelled after the average common technical itinerary in the 3 countries including crop rotation; absence of irrigation (flax fields are not irrigated in western Europe, barring exceptional circumstances); reasoned use of fertiliser and pesticide; and 100% dew retting. It is 100% specific of Western Europe and cannot be used to represent any other geography. The detailed technical itinerary is available from the Alliance. ;The process starts with the intermediate crop sown before flax in the Autum. It then includes preparing the field for sowing, sowing, inputs. Then flax is pulled and laid evenly in the field (around early July depending on weather) , where it will ret over the course of the next 3-7 weeks, depending on climatic conditions. During retting, microorganisms from the soil develop on the plants thanks to dew, rain and wind, leading to partial decomposition of the stem pectins that is key for flax quality. To achieve optimal retting, flax is turned midway through retting, and then finally, the retted stems are baled. The average yield is 6572.66 kg retted plant per ha. Application of fertilizers is included with N, P, K 168 kg-ha, the total N uptake is considered to be 72 kg/ha, only partially reintegrated with N fertilization, the remaining is from previous crop residues and organic matter mineralization. Transport from field to scutching is not included. This dataset has been modelled with the same activity data as the European Flax™ dataset in the Environmental Footprint 3.1 official database (data from the Alliance for European Flax-Linen & Hemp), however LCIA results are slightly different for some indicators, mainly due to different background datasets used.

The activity begins with the destruction (green manure) of intermediate crop and preparation of land for sowing.

The activity ends with the harvesting of the flax straw, dew-retted plant that is ready to be processed into the scutching process. Transport from field to scutching is excluded.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0116:Growing of fibre crops

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The data refer to 5 croping cycles from 2014 harvest until and including 2018 harvest .
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The data represent a weighted average across the 3 European countries producing flax:  France, Belgium and the Netherlands.  This production is 100% certified to European Flax™ and represents 3/4 of the global production for flax long fibre.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The data refer to the average agricultural technical itinerary for the geography given.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The data on inputs to the field activities are collected directly from the Alliance for European Flax-Linen & Hemp. The ecoinvent LCI calculation tool for crop production was used to calculate field emissions from the cultivation process.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data collection has been performed by the Alliance for European Flax-Linen & Hemp from referent sources incl. Arvalis and Inagro (agronomic institutes referent respectively for France and for Belgium-Netherlands) for average agricultural technical itinerary practiced in these 3 countries; and interbranch production statistics. These data represent the European production which is 100% certified to European Flax (TM) and amounts for 3/4 of the global production for fibre, flax, long, scutched on 2023.

exchanges.description: It is sowed at about 115 kg of seeds per hectare for a density of 1500-1600 viable plants per m². Note: Alliance/CELC study considers seeds as co-product of scutching; more precisely in Europe 90% of fibre flax seed production is a co-product of fibre flax cutivation and 10% are grown primarily for seed, where yields of fibre, straw etc. are different.

25 kg woven PP bags are most used for fertiliser packaging. It is assumed conservatively 100 g/m2, add 10% extra for the edges overlap and cutting losses. It results in 0.50*0.80*2*1.1 = 0.88 m2/bag = 88 g/bag per 25 kg fertiliser. The sum of the solid fertiliser including lime and also the linseeds input is maximum of 762 kg/ha and harvest --> 30.5 (31) bags would be required. In sum per ha and harvest hence 31 pieces * 88g/piece = 2.73 kg bags (conservatively). per kg flax plant harvested hence 0.00041536 kg PP bag,

exchanges.description: This value has been provided by the Alliance for European Flax-Linen & Hemp. Calculated value. Land use change (LUC) combines land transformation areas calculated with the adapted 'Direct Land Use Change Assessment Tool' version 2014 developed by Blonk Consultants and the carbon losses from soil organic carbon (SOC) and vegetation (VEG) as calculated in ecoinvent v3. See 'WFLDB-Guidelines.pdf', available at https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/File/Reports. The value is then divided by the yield per ha.
